title: Introduction to Visual Studies
description:
Faculty: Linda Zhang - E: linda.zhang@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: CORE 101 Global Humanities and Social Change
* This course serves as a pre-requisite for most intermediate and advanced Art and Media Studies courses.
---
Course Description:
Images function as both a practical artistic medium (in advertisements for example) but also as something to be aesthetically enjoyed. They can also serve as a medium for social change as images can spread awareness about important issues and, in the digital age, reach huge numbers of people regardless of the language they speak. To better understand how images function, this course introduces students from a variety of backgrounds and interests to interdisciplinary approaches to visual studies, culture, and theory. We will learn how to analyze, evaluate, and interpret images across multiple cultural realms, including art and popular media, public and political space, advertising and commerce, and cinematic and virtual worlds. 
Students will develop a sound foundation in relevant theories such as the gaze, agency, semiology, the exhibitionary order, and spectatorship. Throughout the course, we will also consider how visual technologies have been crucial to the construction and representation of diverse subjectivities, and how they have intersected with broader economic, political, and cultural developments such as colonialism and globalization. Topics will be organized through three interrelated and mutually constitutive thematic units: Technologies of Vision; Spaces of Vision/Envisioning Space; and Global Visual Culture. Each unit will be concluded through a project taking creative and critical visual and/or textual form. 
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
analyze a variety of visual mediums through a critical lens
formulate arguments employing relevant theories in order to discuss visual texts
compose essays that use appropriate vocabulary to interpret and historicize visual texts
---

GLOBAL VISUAL CULTURES

14. Paper consultations

title: Introduction to Video and Film Production
description:
Faculty: Trinh Dinh Le Minh - Email: minh.trinh@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
This video and film production course will introduce students to the basic elements of recording and combining image and sound using various kinds of digital equipment. We will also explore important technical and theoretical concepts associated with the moving image, such as editing, dialectic, representation, and protest. We will cover basic narrative structure and script writing, but will go beyond traditional understandings of moving image-based production to explore more experimental modes of storytelling and filmic practice. The course will emphasize practical engagement with ideas and theories through process and presentation, so hands-on production and formal presentation of work will be prioritized. Course assessments will consist of two key projects: one based on found footage and the other using original shot footage. A core component of these assessments will be presentation and engagement on critique days.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student will be able to:
1. Demonstrate a basic understanding of the video making process.
2. Develop skills in basic script writing format and understanding of filmic narrative structure.
3. Develop comprehension of non-linear editing concepts and practical competency in the usage of non-linear video-editing software.
4. Demonstrate competency in oral presentation and engagement in studio critique.
---

title: Dance and Performance Production
description:
Visiting Faculty: Alexander Tu Nguyen - E: alexander.nguyen@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
This course will introduce students to both the theoretical and practical fundamentals of dance, and the ways in which dance performances are produced. In addition, we will study selected topics in the history of dance, both in its local and international aspects, and the impact of dance within Vietnam and beyond in the 21st century. We will explore the theoretical concepts of movement and apply them through practice to build students’ foundations in movement, and learn how to develop a sense of rhythm, timing, rhythmical expression, and musicality as key to the creative process of dance. Health and safety components are essential in the development of a performer, therefore, students will obtain fundamental knowledge of the mechanics of the body. This course will also offer an opportunity to explore the intricate process and progress of a performance. Students will learn about the different elements of a production, including routine development, staging, formations, and presentation, and critically examine and analyze movement and dance from different styles of commercial dance. Throughout the course, students will work on incremental activities in preparation for a final production and execution of a performance.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
1. Analyze the basic components of a dance performance/routine
2. Develop fundamental skills in movement [e.g., technique, execution, coordination]
3. Demonstrate the key elements of dance [e.g., rhythm, musicality]
4. Acquire the necessary practical knowledge and skills to create and showcase a dance performance.
---

title: 2D/3D Foundations
description:
Faculty: Richard Streitmatter-Tran - E: Richard.Tran@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts and Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description
2D/3D Foundations is a practice-based studio course introducing the fundamentals of visual language including shape, light, composition, color theory, perspective and materiality. Students will apply visual principles to class-directed exercises and assessments. Students will have an opportunity to work in a variety of media including graphite, charcoal, watercolor and modeling clay. Students may also have the opportunity to visit an art exhibition, an artist's studio, or an event off-campus. This course serves as a foundation for studio art practice and provides students a practical counterbalance to theoretical aspects of the AMS major. More broadly, the course may benefit other majors with design foci such as engineering and computer science. There is a list of personal supplies that students must purchase for the course. It is estimated that the total cost will be around 500,000 VND.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1. Demonstrate a solid command of visual literacy and principles (e.g. line, value, measurement, proportion) applied to 2D and 3D artworks and exercises.
CLO2. Identify art-historical references, methods and techniques
CLO3. Analyze, evaluate and discuss artwork in formal art critique
CLO4. Communicate ideas through making and articulate their process while developing their unique individual style
CLO5. Write an artwork statement
---
Tentative Schedule
*Draft Outline. Course content by session. Order and details may change.

Section 1: Introduction to the Course
The course overview and assessments, readings and required materials. An introduction to point, line and space.

Section 2: Fundamentals of Visual Literacy
Students will be introduced to the fundamentals of visual literacy: contrast/harmony, balance, order/stress, direction, texture, scale, motion.

Section 3: Perspective, Depth and Technical Drawing
Students will be introduced to fundamentals of perspective including dimension, foreground, midground and background, foreshortening, atmospheric perspective, axonometric and conical perspective and applying theory to practice in isometric, 1, 2, and 3-point perspective drawings.

Section 4: Light and Shape
Students will be introduced to the language of light including value, variance/key, contrast, midtone, key light, shadow, highlight, reflection, hard/soft/diffuse light, chiaroscuro, white balance. Examples of visual language of light will be applied to the analysis and creation of arts and design work.

+++Sketchbook Submission, Part 1++++

Section 5: Color Theory
Students will learn about basic color theory including primary, secondary and tertiary colors through color wheels; complimentary, triadic and analogous color; color temperature and color terminology (hue, value, chroma, tint, tone, shade, grays). Students will also be introduced to several historical theories of color from Newton, Albers and Munsell. They will understand the differences between RGB (Screen based) and CMYK (Print based) color spaces, and limited color palettes. Students will apply color theory through color mixing exercises.

Section 6: Composition
Students will learn about visual composition including the golden ratio, the rule of thirds, symmetry, balance, focal points, proportion with examples in art, design, photography and film. Students will be selecting an image and analyzing it in terms of composition and using it as a reference for a new artwork. Subsection: How to write an Artist Statement.

Section 7: Materiality in Collage and Assemblage
Students will experiment with collage and assemblage using found materials to make expressive artworks that recontextualize the source materials with new meaning. Students will be exposed to art works from history that have used collage and assemblage.

Section 8: Modeling Form
An introduction to sculpture from modeling to carving.

Section 9: Ergonomics and Human Centered Design
Students will learn about the history of human-centered design, universal design and ergonomics. Students will be analyzing objects from everyday life in terms of usability and aesthetics and submitting a “re-design” of an object or product.

+++Assemblage Assignment Due+++

Section 10: Contemporary Art Gallery or Artist Studio Visit
Students are introduced to the professional contemporary art practice through the gallery and/or artist studio.

Section 11: Final Project Work-in-Progress
Students will present their final projects work in progress for informal peer and instructor feedback. Students will take feedback into consideration as they continue the development their semester project work in terms of concept and form.

+++Sketchbook Submission, Part 2++++

Section 12: Final Project Critique Part 1 (50% of class)
Students will present their final projects work in progress in class critiques. Students will learn about the value of constructive criticism, both in giving and receiving.

Section 13: Final Project Critique Part 2 (50% of class)
Students will present their final projects work in progress in class critiques. Students will learn about the value of constructive criticism, both in giving and receiving.

Section 14: Final Course Review
We will reflect on the principles of visual language and discuss how those principles have been applied to the works created over the semester and how they should continue to inform their studies both in theory and practice.

Readings from:
Donis A. Donis. A Primer of Visual Literacy. Cambridge: The MIT Press, 1973
Art Fundamentals: Light, shape, color, composition, perspective, depth & anatomy, 2nd Edition. Worcester: 3DTotal Press, 2020
Art Fundamentals: Theory in Practice. Worcester: 3DTotal Press, 2021
Mariko Higaki. Observational Sketching: How to Draw Almost Any Object. Beverly: Quarto, 2020
Richard Yot. Light for Visual Artists: Understanding and Using Light in Art and Design, 2nd Edition. London: Laurence King Publishing, 2020.
Emiel Heijnen & Melissa Bremmer (eds). Wicked Arts Assignments: Practicing creativity in contemporary arts education. Amsterdam: Valiz, 2021.
Heather Darcy Bhandari & Jonathan Melber. Art/Work. New York: Free Press, 2009.
---
Possible Assessments & Grading
Engagement (20%)
Students are expected to fully engage in class and online discussions and critiques. Be proactive in their independent learning and sharing of knowledge throughout the course. While it is understood that more than two unexcused absences will result in a failing the course, there is no mark for attendance.

Studio Journal 30%
(Two submissions, 15% each)
The journal is a critical component of the artist’s and designer’s studio practice. It serves as a depository for ideas, a record of process and a platform for the development of observational skill. Students will be required to keep an A3 sized notebook journal for the class. The journal will also contain exercises completed in class and assigned homework. Students will be assessed on the completeness of the journal, the use of the journal in terms of student-directed learning, frequency and experimentation, and how it reflects the evolution of their ideas in relation to the final project.

Assemblage Art 20%
Students will combine two visual principles or elements (e.g. shape, line, rhythm, contrast, symmetry, pattern/repetition, weight, transparency, color, etc) to create a unique assemblage using both studio and found materials. Students will be writing an artwork statement explaining how their selected principle has been interpreted and realized in the artwork.

Final Project 30%
The student will conceive of one final project for the semester in the media of their choice (e.g, drawing, painting, sculpture, digital art, installation, etc). The final project will have benchmarks that include sketching, a written statement, class critique and final projection and presentation. These benchmarks will be factored into the final assessment of the project.

title: Global Modern Art
description:
Faculty: Pamela Corey - E: pamela.corey@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: ARTS 101 Introduction to Visual Studies.
Reading/Writing: Intensive
---
Course Description:
This course introduces students to significant artists and movements in modern art from the nineteenth century to the 1960s. A key area of investigation will be how the concepts of modernity and modernism have been expressed by artists in reaction to major technological and geopolitical developments in the twentieth century. We will situate artworks within their local contexts while remaining attentive to the transnational nature of certain movements. This postcolonial approach decenters the Eurocentric narrative of modern art and emphasizes how modernism emerged from sites of exchange and encounter between artistic communities in Asia, Europe, Africa, the United States, and Latin America. While students will gain familiarity with movements or themes such as realism, cubism, primitivism, surrealism, the Bauhaus, abstraction, and pop, a comparative approach to these practices in a global context (e.g., surrealist art in Paris and Cairo, abstraction in New York and Osaka) will help us better understand how modernism forged new directions in the nature of artistic representation, and more particularly, the artist’s sense of their role in society and the larger world.

---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Define modernity and modernism in the context of art history.
Identify important modern art movements and artists across a global comparative context.
Demonstrate competency in visual analysis, textual interpretation, and the use of art historical terminology.
Analyze the connections between the formal attributes of artworks and their relevant historical, political, and cultural contexts.
---

title: Issues in Contemporary Photography
description:
Faculty: Tram Luong - E: tram.luong@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: ART 101 Introduction to Visual Studies AND ART 103 Introduction to Photography History and Theory AND SOCI 102 Social Inquiry and the Social Sciences
* Cross-listed course in Social Studies (SOCI)
---
Course Description:
Issues in Contemporary Photography offers fresh perspectives on existing debates in the field of photography. It aims to deepen students’ understanding of photography—its historical development, aesthetic considerations, and pictorial strategies—through hands-on engagement with styles and concepts. The course provides an opportunity for students to expand their technical and creative range through weekly assignments and critique sessions. Students will learn the basics of digital cameras, image-editing software, and key photographic techniques. Students will examine photographic works from internationally celebrated photographers to arrive at their own understanding of how photographic images are created, reproduced, and valued within both fine art photography and photography-as-art traditions. As such, they will learn to develop conceptual ideas, offer constructive critique to their peers, and locate their work in the broader context of contemporary photographic practice. Topics for discussion include visual ambiguity, objectivity, staging, authenticity, the digital and the analogue, and AI influence on photography, among others.
Students are strongly encouraged to use their own DSLR cameras.

---
Course Learning Outcomes:
After this course, students should be able to
1. Cultivate an enhanced appreciation of photography as an artistic practice, to be considered across different cultural and social contexts.
2. Adopt a critical, research-led approach to image-making in the photographic tradition.
3. Strengthen key skills and techniques of photographic image-making necessary for higher level practicum-based courses in the Art and Media Studies major and other related disciplines.
4. Communicate photographic ideas with clarity, precision, and eloquence.
5. Create a photographic portfolio that responds to a wide range of conceptual, theoretical and social considerations.
6. Develop an interdisciplinary mindset towards photography and its impact in academia and society.

This is meant to foster a welcoming artistic space and familiarize students with the idea of open communication.
Weekly Photographic Assignment (20%): Every week, students are asked to produce a series of photographs in response to the materials introduced in class. The prompts range from technical consideration, formal strategies, to conceptual ideas. Weekly photographic assignments will be showcased and discussed in class the following week, sometimes in the presence of practicing photographers and artists based in Ho Chi Minh City. The assignment is meant to guide students’ practices of looking at and making conceptually rich photographs.

title: Memories, Screens, and Theaters in Contemporary Chinese-Language Cinema
description:
Faculty: Linda Zhang - E: linda.zhang@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: ARTS 101 Introduction to Visual Studies and ARTS 105 Introduction to Film History and Theory
Reading/Writing: Intensive
---
Course Description:
When was the last time you watched a film at the movie theater? We are living in a time after the pandemic where movie theater seems to be becoming obsolete, especially due to shifts in viewing and industry practices towards streaming distribution. In turn, we should question how shifts in viewing and screening practices change how we define the cinematic experience. The course offers a new way to think about the changing spectatorship practices while also introducing Chinese-language cinema from Mainland China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong since the late 1980s. Through research and writing assignments, we will focus on questions of not only where these films were produced and directed, but also how and where they were screened around the world. We will investigate past, current, and evolving viewing practices, not just in terms of circulation and screening, but also in terms of how the movie theater and theater-going are represented and commemorated within these films. Introducing major theoretical and historical scholarship on contemporary Chinese language cinema, we will consider how memories, screens, and theaters concretize the pleasure of viewing and imagining through film and media.

---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1. Students will be able to demonstrate familiarity with filmwork and filmmakers from China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.
CLO2. Students will be able to analyze films and theoretical texts, and to be able to annotate with proficiency in filmic (visual, audio) formal techniques;
CLO3. Students will be able to write, construct, and present reviews, rationales, and essays into a clear, original, and persuasive interpretive claims, in both oral and written formats

title: Advanced Topics in Painting
description:
Faculty: Richard Streitmatter-Tran - E: Richard.tran@fulbright.edu.vn
Pre-requisite: ARTS 101 Introduction to Visual Studies AND ARTS 107 2D/3D Foundations
---
Course Description:
This course will expand upon art fundamentals through the development of an oil painting practice for both traditional and contemporary painting methods including direct (alla prima) and indirect painting (imprimatur, grisaille, chiaroscuro, glazing) and limited palettes. Topics covered will include painting tools and paint, preparation processes for painting canvas supports, sizes and grounds, medium, varnishes, pigments, solvents, painting procedures, and the care of finished paintings. Students will learn the history of oil painting and be introduced to a selection of artists for insight on painting concepts, styles and techniques. Exercises and assessments will focus on developing a structured painting process. Class discussions and critiques will assist the student in developing and defending their painting concepts. There is a list of personal supplies that students must purchase for the course. It is estimated that the total cost will be around 1,000,000 VND.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1. Demonstrate advanced skill in a variety of painting methods
CLO2. Identify art-historical references, artists, styles, methods and techniques
CLO3. Analyze, evaluate and discuss artwork in formal art critique
CLO4. Communicate ideas through making and articulate their process while developing their unique individual style
CLO5. Write an artist statement
---
Tentative Syllabus:
Section 1: Introduction to the Course
The course overview and assessments, readings, required materials, art studio and safety protocols. Students will learn about the history of oil paint. Instructor will accompany students to the art store to assist them in purchasing their personal supplies for the next class.

Section 2: Introduction to Oil Painting
Students will be introduced to oil paint, mediums, and solvents. A review of color theory (with specific application to oil paint). 
Exercise: Color mixing with oils. Students will create a color chart using the Munsell method (value, hue, chroma) and a skin-tone reference chart.

Section 3: Preparing the Support
Students will learn how to stretch canvas and prepare the support for painting with layers of gesso. Students will prepare the large 80 x 60 support that will be used later in the semester for their final project.
Homework: Students will research and identify three painters working in oil whose style they want to emulate or are inspired by. The styles of these painters will be referenced by students in the successive class exercises and assessments, as students strive to learn from them.

Section 4: Introduction to Alla Prima
Students will be introduced to the Alla Prima (All at Once) direct method of painting, where the painting is completed within one to three days, allowing the students to work wet-on-wet, including impasto painting. We will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working with this method. Students will be introduced to artists and artworks related to Alla Prima painting, notably in portraiture and in plein-air painting. 
Exercise: Students begin the Alla Prima painting assessment, due next class.

Section 5: Limited Palette 
Students will be introduced to a limited palette (e.g. The Zorn Palette). Students will study works that utilize a limited palette including Anders Zorn, Caravaggio, John Singer Sargent and Alpay Efe. 
Exercise: Students will be map out the Zorn Palette as preparation for the Assessment 2: The Limited Palette Painting. 

+++ASSESSMENT 1: Alla Prima Painting Due++++

Section 6: Introduction to Plein Air Painting
Students will be introduced to Plein Air (outdoor) painting, another direct painting method using paint directly from the tube to create a painting in the impressionistic style. 
Exercise: Choosing an appropriate site for plein air painting, students will work on site to complete a small plein air painting by the end of class.

Section 7: Introduction to Indirect Painting
Students will be introduced to the Indirect Painting method where the painting is constructed in layers of paint. Beginning with the sketch, imprimatur, grisaille (tonal underpainting) toward latter applications of paint in layers (fat over lean principle, glazing). This section will begin the series of painting phases culminating in a completed painting and Final Project Assessment.
Exercise: Students will work on research material and draw sketches for their final project and prepare sketches for transfer on prepared toned canvas.

+++ASSESSMENT 2: Limited Palette Painting Due ++++

Section 8: Painting the Grisaille
Students will learn the process of creating the tonal grisaille painting. Students will complete the grisaille of painting for the next application of color in the next class.

Section 9: First Application of Color
Utilizing the fat-over-lean principle in oil painting, students will add the first lean layer of paint over the underpainting. Introduction to glazing, the addition of color using semi-transparent oil paints. *Note that direct painting requires a layer to be completely dry before painting upon. A week will be necessary for thinner layers to be ready for new layers of paint. Oil drying mediums may be used (such as Liquitex) to quicken drying times.

Section 10: Successive Applications of Paint
Students will continue toward the completion of their paintings adding new layers of color upon the dried underlayer. Focus on edge and brushstroke variation.

Section 11: Finishing the Indirect Painting 
Students will work to finish their paintings with final layers and details.

Section 12: Final Project Critique Part 1 (50% of class)
Students will present their final projects work in progress in class critiques. Students will learn about the value of constructive criticism, both in giving and receiving. 

+++ASSESSMENT 3: Final Project Paintings are due +++

Section 13: Final Project Critique Part 2 (50% of class)
Students will present their final projects work in progress in class critiques. Students will learn about the value of constructive criticism, both in giving and receiving. 

Section 14: Final Course Review
We will reflect on the studio practice of oil painting and discuss ways to continue experimentation with the medium for future works.

Students are expected to participate fully in class and online discussions. Students are expected to fully engage with the courses in which they are enrolled including classes, seminars, exhibitions, and other events.

description:
Faculty: Nguyen Thanh Trung - E: trung.nguyen@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Core
Reading/Writing: Intensive
---
Course Description:
This course exposes students to a wide array of issues encountered in modern Vietnam, ranging from socio-cultural, politico-economic aspects to questions of nationalism, international relations, and globalization when examining the country in its regional and global contexts. Throughout the course, students are introduced to basic concepts in social sciences and humanities that will allow them a better understanding of their social environments as well as urge them to assess others’ interpretations with an open but critical mind. The course helps to raise students’ socio-political awareness and cultural identity, encouraging them to grow up as responsible national and global citizens.
---
Course Learning Outcomes: After finishing the course, the students should be able to:
1. Form a multidimensional view of contemporary Vietnam built upon the interdisciplinary foundation of Vietnamese Studies
2. Understand (Vietnamese) culture and society with an open but critical mind: identify problems critically from any given discourses, come up with a strong argument based on substantial evidence, and solve the identified problems logically;
3. Conduct an appropriate research project independently or with a team;
4. Present the results of the research project convincingly and creatively in various formats;
5. Recognize and respect the diversities of communities and cultures with open-mindedness; and
6. Strengthen students’ civic identity by demonstrating themselves as both Vietnamese and global citizens.
---

Attendance & Participation: 15%

title: Quantitative Reasoning for a Digital Age
description:
Faculty: Ngoc Phan - E: ngoc.phan@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Core
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description: Digital technology transforms the way we live, from how we travel to what we use for money, to how we swipe to find love. At the heart of these social, cultural, and economic changes lie mathematics and computer science. But how do we gather the information, interpret the data, and construct the algorithms that drive these advances and affect our lives? Quantitative Reasoning in a Digital Age not only develops foundational skills in mathematics and computer science, but demonstrates how computer programming and algorithmic thinking inform issues in fields as diverse as economics, psychology, history, and philosophy. Structured around project-based teamwork, students will examine how the toolkit of computational thinking can model human behavior and address real-world problems in business, education, public health, government, and other sectors. By understanding how quantitative reasoning affects modern society and modern society often affects our quantitative reasoning, students will learn to question their own assumptions about data big and small and think critically about the abundance of quantitative information that defines the decisions we make.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Students will be able to:
1. Formulate research questions and collect appropriate data to address these questions
2. Critically examine and identify patterns in quantitative data
3. Investigate mathematical models computationally
4. Effectively work in teams
---

title: Scientific Inquiry
description:
Faculty: Hoang Minh To Nga - E: nga.hoang@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Core
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
Scientific Inquiry unlocks the door to discovery and explores how humans acquired our fundamental knowledge of the sciences. By engaging foundational texts and practices from across various scientific disciplines, students will understand the various processes involved in acquiring scientific knowledge and how these processes are applied to contemporary scientific questions. Students will critically analyze the claims and evidence presented in the primary literature and use a project- and inquiry-based approach to answer important scientific questions across the various disciplines of the natural sciences. The course also focuses on understanding how to make, interpret, and challenge scientific claims by conducting original research, and communicating the results in written reports and oral presentations. Creating connections across the Fulbright core curriculum, this course emphasizes how scientific inquiry informs public debates past and present, challenging students not only to understand the world from a scientific perspective, but also to understand how our scientific perspective shapes and is shaped by the world around us.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students will:
1. Demonstrate understanding of the historical development of key scientific ideas through written communication;
2. Demonstrate ability to critically evaluate scientific claims through written and/or spoken communication;
3. Demonstrate ability to apply the process of scientific inquiry through forming scientific questions & hypotheses as well as collecting, analyzing, interpreting, and reporting data;
4. Demonstrate basic competence in quantitative data analysis by applying the relevant skills to a collaborative project.
---
Possible Assessments & Grading:
Writing & speaking assignments, quizzes, and collaborative projects will be used to assess students’ understanding and application of the concepts and methods related to the course

title: Design and Systems Thinking
description:
Faculty: Phung Manh Duong - E: duong.phung@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Core
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
We learn across the Fulbright Core how transformations have happened in human history – transformations in thought, in social structures, and in individual lives. We also see how transformations happen in nature and how human intervention transforms the natural world. But what about transformation that humans create through intentional design? This might be a new mask that filters air in a superior manner, a drone that can deliver medicines to remote parts of the country faster than any vehicle, or an app that allows you to create new music depending on your mood. In this course, we showcase how innovation is linked to rigorous scientific, mathematical, and engineering methods, with an emphasis on teamwork and hands-on experience. Students may take this as an entry point into the deeper study of design and engineering, or they may apply what they learn in this introductory course to their understanding of social and economic systems, to creative fabrication in the fine arts, or to the design and development of a start-up company in collaboration with Fulbright’s Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation. This course embraces both the art and science of creation, instilling the confidence to experiment, sometimes to fail, but ultimately to prevail in designing and building a better future. Designing and Systems Thinking (D&ST) course introduces the principles, processes, and tools of systems thinking and design thinking that are used to identify and generate solutions to frictions in our society. The building blocks to understand systems and to approach the designing process include: how ethnographic observation can be used to frame and observe real world challenges from the consumer’s perspective; an introduction to systems thinking to understand how challenges exist in a broader context; design thinking, enabling a structured approach to developing solutions and concepts; prototyping of physical products and designs; and key engineering concepts that enable concepts to become reality. This course employs project-based learning among teams of students to identify problems, specify client, consumer, or societal needs, and design a system answering those needs. This process includes defining the product’s features and specifications, decomposing it into components, integrating it into an environment, building it, and then validating and verifying its results. For example, teams may create elements of a smart home like automatic lighting and watering, or an Internet of Things (IoT) system for drought monitoring and early warning, or an automatic hand sanitizer. They will use modules, materials, tools, and facilities available in the market or in the Fulbright Maker Space to prototype these systems. In the process, they will develop a basic command of agile methods used in project management, learn basic modern fabrication skills, and practice critical thinking, including an understanding of constraints, negotiating between options, and examining social and environmental impact.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to
1. Understand and practice the tools and principles of systems thinking and design thinking.
2. Define the requirements of potential solutions and the quantitative and qualitative specifications of a system, with consideration for potentially related factors.
3. Decompose a system into deterministic components and functions, explain how they interact with each other and behave when integrated as a whole system, and explain how the system works within its environment.
4. Build a working prototype and verify whether this prototype meets defined requirements and specifications.
5. Improve communication skills through oral and written presentations, sharpen teamwork skills by working with other students on term projects, as well as critical thinking while giving comments to others.
---
Possible Assessments & Grading:
Maker Space Training: 20%

title: Design and Systems Thinking
description:
Faculty: Truong Trung Kien - E: kien.truong@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Core
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
We learn across the Fulbright Core how transformations have happened in human history – transformations in thought, in social structures, and in individual lives. We also see how transformations happen in nature and how human intervention transforms the natural world. But what about transformation that humans create through intentional design? This might be a new mask that filters air in a superior manner, a drone that can deliver medicines to remote parts of the country faster than any vehicle, or an app that allows you to create new music depending on your mood. In this course, we showcase how innovation is linked to rigorous scientific, mathematical, and engineering methods, with an emphasis on teamwork and hands-on experience. Students may take this as an entry point into the deeper study of design and engineering, or they may apply what they learn in this introductory course to their understanding of social and economic systems, to creative fabrication in the fine arts, or to the design and development of a start-up company in collaboration with Fulbright’s Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation. This course embraces both the art and science of creation, instilling the confidence to experiment, sometimes to fail, but ultimately to prevail in designing and building a better future. Designing and Systems Thinking (D&ST) course introduces the principles, processes, and tools of systems thinking and design thinking that are used to identify and generate solutions to frictions in our society. The building blocks to understand systems and to approach the designing process include: how ethnographic observation can be used to frame and observe real world challenges from the consumer’s perspective; an introduction to systems thinking to understand how challenges exist in a broader context; design thinking, enabling a structured approach to developing solutions and concepts; prototyping of physical products and designs; and key engineering concepts that enable concepts to become reality. This course employs project-based learning among teams of students to identify problems, specify client, consumer, or societal needs, and design a system answering those needs. This process includes defining the product’s features and specifications, decomposing it into components, integrating it into an environment, building it, and then validating and verifying its results. For example, teams may create elements of a smart home like automatic lighting and watering, or an Internet of Things (IoT) system for drought monitoring and early warning, or an automatic hand sanitizer. They will use modules, materials, tools, and facilities available in the market or in the Fulbright Maker Space to prototype these systems. In the process, they will develop a basic command of agile methods used in project management, learn basic modern fabrication skills, and practice critical thinking, including an understanding of constraints, negotiating between options, and examining social and environmental impact.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to
1. Understand and practice the tools and principles of systems thinking and design thinking.
2. Define the requirements of potential solutions and the quantitative and qualitative specifications of a system, with consideration for potentially related factors.
3. Decompose a system into deterministic components and functions, explain how they interact with each other and behave when integrated as a whole system, and explain how the system works within its environment.
4. Build a working prototype and verify whether this prototype meets defined requirements and specifications.
5. Improve communication skills through oral and written presentations, sharpen teamwork skills by working with other students on term projects, as well as critical thinking while giving comments to others.
---

Theory: 40%

Course Description:
How do we develop software that solves problems efficiently and reliably? How do we write programs that work correctly and can be refactored and improved over time? This course continues and expands on content from Computer Science I, with a greater focus on theoretical concepts, abstraction, and larger programs. Topics include object-oriented programming, unit testing and refactoring, basic algorithm analysis, searching and sorting, linear data structures (lists, maps, stacks, and queues), trees, and graphs.

Abstract data types and data structures

Algorithms and analysis
● explain what is meant by the "best'' and "worst'' case behavior of an algorithm,
● determine informally the time and space complexity of simple algorithms and express your answers in big-O notation,
● discuss the runtime and memory efficiency of principal algorithms for sorting, searching and hashing,
● determine whether a recursive or iterative solution is most appropriate for a problem, and
● use recursive backtracking to solve a problem like navigating a maze.
Object oriented programming
● describe how references allow for objects to be accessed in multiple ways and accurately diagram the state of a program during execution,
● design and implement a class, and
● use object-oriented encapsulation mechanisms such as interfaces and private members.
Software design

● apply consistent documentation and program style standards that contribute to the readability and maintainability of software

title: Computational Social Media
description:
Faculty: Phan Thanh Trung - E: trung.phan@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Maths & Computing (E4)
Pre-requisite: No. Completion of CS101-Computer Science I or MATH105-Introduction to Data Analysis may be helpful, but this course is explicitly open to students from other disciplines as well. Please discuss your background with the instructor if you are unsure.
---
Course Description:
The course will present a human-centered view of computational social media. It uses a multidisciplinary approach and integrates concepts from media studies, multimedia information systems, machine learning, and network science to present the socio-technical fundamentals needed to understand the motivations, characterize the behavior, and analyze the content and relations of social media users and communities in sites like Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube. Students will become familiar with computational approaches for classification, discovery, and interpretation of phenomena in social media. The content is organized around trends in social media, introducing computational models of general applicability.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Students will be able to:
1. Describe a brief history of social media and networked individualism encompassing friending (Facebook), tweeting (Twitter), shooting (Instagram), moving (Foursquare), and watching (YouTube)
2. Apply multimedia techniques (audio, video, text) to analyze social media from Twitter, YouTube, Foursquare, etc.
3. Analyze the content of communities on social media by the behavior of online users.
4. Analyze crowdsourced tasks and workers by the uses of crowdsourcing in social media research and social participation.
5. Explain the characteristics of privacy and social media with their impact on society 6. Design a multidisciplinary project by integrated concepts from media studies, multimedia information systems, machine learning, and network science and implement it on downloaded datasets from social media.
---
Schedule of Topics
1. Introduction. A brief history of social media. Networked individualism.
2. Friending. A human-centered review of Facebook research. Users, communities, and networks. The real-name web.
3. Tweeting. From random chatter to worldwide pulse. Followers, hashtags, events, and network effects. Analyzing real-life phenomena on Twitter. Misinformation in social media.
4. Shooting. Photo sharing and tagging. Media, user and community analysis enabled by photo sharing. Ephemeral social media.
5. Moving. Location-based social networks. Individual and network phenomena revealed by mobility data. Urban computing.
6. Watching. YouTube as a media phenomenon. Multimedia techniques (audio, video, text) to analyze social video.
7. Crowdsourcing. Models to analyze crowdsourced tasks and workers. Uses of crowdsourcing in social media research. Crowdsourcing and social participation.
8. Society. Privacy and social media. Effects of social media on society.
---

---
Course Description:
Dive into the fascinating world of game theory, where mathematics meets psychology, economics, and strategy! In this dynamic undergraduate course, you'll unravel the mysteries behind how individuals make decisions in strategic situations. From the competitive arenas of business negotiations and political campaigns to the cooperative dynamics of family disputes and social interactions, game theory offers a lens to understand the choices people make.
Ever wondered why two countries might choose peace over war? Or how companies decide on pricing strategies? Or why some social dilemmas remain unsolved? Game theory holds the answers.
Throughout this course, you'll:
Decode classic games like the Prisoner's Dilemma and the Stag Hunt.
Explore real-world applications, from monopolistic competition and bargaining to voting and alliances.
Delve into advanced topics like evolutionary game theory, signaling, and behavioral game theory.
Engage in interactive experiments, group discussions, and case studies that bring theoretical concepts to life.
By the end of this journey, you'll not only master the art and science of strategic thinking but also gain a toolkit of analytical skills applicable to a wide range of fields. Whether you're an aspiring economist, a budding entrepreneur, or just a curious mind, this course promises a deep dive into the intricate dance of decision-making. Come and unlock the game theorist in you!
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
CLO1: define and explain core concepts of game theory, distinguishing between cooperative and non-cooperative games, simultaneous and sequential games, and games with complete and incomplete information.
CLO2: represent strategic situations using game theoretic models such as normal form (matrix) and extensive form (game trees) and determine equilibria using techniques like backward induction and iterated elimination of dominated strategies.
CLO3: apply game theoretic concepts to analyze real-world strategic interactions in various fields, recognizing the implications of game theory in scenarios like the prisoner's dilemma.
CLO4: critically evaluate the assumptions underlying game theoretic models, reflecting on their limitations and considering how real-world behavior might deviate from theoretical predictions.

This course delves into the multifaceted world of corruption, exploring its definitions, causes, consequences, and potential remedies. title: Signals, Systems and Control
description:
Faculty: Truong Trung Kien - E: kien.truong@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Sciences & Engineering (E3)
Pre-requisites: CORE105 Design and Systems Thinking
---
Course Description: 
Signals are everywhere. By definition, a signal is any observable change in quantity over space or time. It could help observers to obtain information about a phenomenon. In nature, signals can be actions done by organisms to alert other organisms or sounds or motions by animals to alert other animals of danger or food. Advances in technology have improved the capabilities of human beings to identify, analyze and even synthesize diverse information sources such as audio (speech, acoustics, music), image (photos, videos, multimedia, medical scans), medical signals (heart rate, blood pressure, brain activity) and remote sensing data (geophysical, sensing, radar). In principle, signals could be represented as data values or abstractly as mathematical expressions. A system converts or manipulate an input signal into an output signal. Examples of systems are face recognition, video streaming, cellular phones, and smart homes. In this course, students will learn to use mathematical theory and computer simulation to develop models, to analyze and to manipulate signals and systems that vary in continuous-time and discrete time. Specifically, the course covers representation of signals and systems, systems properties, conversion between continuous-time and discrete-time, Laplace, Fourier and z-transforms, transfer functions, frequency responses, convolution, stability, feedback and control systems. Students will gain hands-on experience on how to process various types of signals and to analyze and design systems by computer simulation using MATLAB or a similar software package.
---
Course Learning Outcomes: 
After the course, students will be able to
Demonstrate understanding of the key concepts and mathematical representation models of signals and systems.
Strengthen their engineering skills involved in the design, analyze and simulation of systems process input signals in order to produce the desired outputs or to control the systems’ behaviors.
Deepen their grasp of programming concepts and their programming skills.
Work effectively as a team to complete group assignments on practical signal processing applications.
Communicate clearly their results via professional report writing and presentation.

description:
Visiting Faculty: Philip Catton
Category: Exploratory - Arts & Humanities (E1); Exploratory - Social Sciences (E2)

---
Course Description:
The Spanish-American War of 1898 marked the entry of the United States into a new era of global engagement, as it administered populous overseas territories, engaged actively in spreading its liberal ideology and socio-economic vision, and reframed its conceptions of national and international security. Since then, it has become the leading global power, whose foreign policy not only disproportionately impacts other nations, but shapes the very structure of the international system. A grasp of American diplomatic history has become indispensable to anyone wishing to understand international politics from the beginning of the 20th century onwards.
This course examines the evolution of American foreign policy through the 20th century, covering all the major events and debates of that time period, including the American decision to intervene in World War I and its consequences; the impact of America’s isolationist foreign policy during the interwar years; the causes and consequences of World War II; the origins of the Cold War and American strategy; the creation and collapse of the American-led postwar economic system; American relations with allies and enemies in the Third World; and the United States in the post-Cold War World. We will also explore a range of macro-themes, including the role of ideology, race, religion, domestic politics, the institutional environment, and individual leaders in the making of American foreign policy.
The goal of the course is to introduce students to the study of American foreign policy after 1898. Students will become familiar with important events, personalities, and theoretical perspectives. Students will be introduced to a range of opinions through secondary sources and trained to properly evaluate and use primary sources. Students will be expected to integrate these sources to produce two medium-length essays of five double-spaced pages each, with clear structures, coherent arguments supported by evidence where appropriate, and correct citation. Students will come away from the course with improved critical reading and argumentative writing skills, which are highly valued in most careers in an information economy.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
Identify and state the significance of key individuals and events that have shaped US global engagement
Explain how ideologies like liberal-internationalism, imperialism and realism have shaped US global engagement in their own words
Explain how American actors have seen the world in their own words
Explain how other peoples and nations have seen the US in the world in their own words

Course Description:
For over 30 years from the end of World War II, a series of interconnected conflicts occurred on the Indochina peninsula. The wars in Vietnam evolved from an anti-colonial struggle into a superpower confrontation and were central to the decades-long global encounter known as the Cold War. As conflict in Vietnam grew in intensity and complexity, it took on increasingly global implications, drawing in a diverse range of rival states and non-state actors.
This course will examine critical historiographical questions, including: What were the Vietnamese origins of the conflict? How and why did anti-colonial Vietnamese become so divided? Why did Cold War superpowers become so deeply involved in Vietnamese affairs? How and why did the conflict end the way it did? And what are the global legacies of the war?
In addition to examining its origins and evolution, the course will use the conflict to explore broader international events and trends, including empire and decolonization, the Chinese Civil War, the Sino-Soviet Split, Détente, and the Cambodian Genocide.

title: Europe on Trial: Law, Politics, and Society since Nuremberg
description:
Faculty: Andrew Harold Bellisari– E: andrew.bellisari@fulbright.edu.vn
Credits: 04 credits
Pre-requisite: Completion of at least one foundation course in History. Students will be expected to have a general knowledge of modern European history.
Reading/Writing: Intensive
---
Course Description: 
In the aftermath of the Second World War, European civilization lay in ruins. Over 36 million people had died, 19 million of whom were civilians. Economic devastation stalked the continent, violent score-settling was common, and near-anarchy reigned in many places. As Europeans came to terms with war and began rebuilding society they looked to legal institutions to take account of atrocities, punish (or forgive) perpetrators, and develop new ideas of justice, accountability, political liberty, and civil rights. Starting with the Nuremberg tribunal, Europeans have used (and abused) court trials to reshape the political, social, and cultural landscape of the continent. As such, trials provide an excellent lens through which to observe how Europeans confronted the most difficult controversies of their time: wartime atrocities, genocide, Stalinism, decolonization, torture, authoritarianism, the fall of Communism, postcolonial immigration, European integration, and the role of religious extremism. This course looks at “trials” real and conceptual to chart European history from 1945 to the present. Using primary sources such as original court transcripts and witness testimonies, students will examine trials for war crimes and treason, military tribunals and “show” trials, trials of terrorists and “counter-terrorists,” as well as contemporary human rights trials. They will also look at how Europeans frequently took matters into their own hands to put the past itself on trial through vigilante justice, the construction or destruction of historical monuments, and the burial and reburial of controversial historical figures. In particular, students will investigate how the same events were tried and retried, their histories told and retold over time as a gauge of Europe’s changing political landscape.
“Europe on Trial” is designed to give Fulbright students a deeper understanding of political, social, and cultural systems beyond Vietnam. At first glance, contemporary Europe looks very different from Vietnam. Yet peace and democratic governance are recent phenomena for Europeans—the ghosts of war, occupation, and authoritarianism still haunt their societies and, as in Vietnam, Europeans also struggle to reassess their past in the face of multi-generational trauma. Students taking this course will witness how and why Europeans have constantly reexamined their past. In so doing, they will better understand Europe’s present and gain a framework for analyzing more universal questions of balancing order with civil liberties, justice, and power beyond the European continent. 
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Understand the historical context, political debates, and socio-cultural transformations that occurred in Europe since 1945.
Compare and contrast how various postwar European political and legal systems deployed the law to address issues of justice, security, democracy, religion, and historical memory.

title: Cults and Conspiracies, Renaissance to Present
description:
Faculty: Elsa Costa – E: elsa.costa@fulbright.edu.vn
Pre-requisite: Completion of all CORE AND at least one course in History, Social Studies, or Psychology
Reading/Writing: Intensive
* Cross-listed with Social Studies (SOCI)
---
Course Description:
This course covers the proliferation of cults and occult beliefs during the Renaissance, their repercussions in the early modern period, and their relationship with the genesis of the modern conspiracy theory, with occult organizations both the subject of conspiracy theories and genitors of conspiracy theories in their own right. Topics covered include Rosicrucianism, Freemasonry (and anti-Masonic conspiracy theories), Sebastianism, the mass hysteria at Loudun, Protestant and Catholic witchcraft panic, Waldensianism, early modern appropriations of Joachim of Fiore (including by Christopher Columbus), Catholic and Protestant conspiracy theories about the other, anti-Jesuit sentiment, the Man in the Iron Mask, the Protocols of the Elders of Zion (an antisemitic modification of earlier conspiracies unrelated to Judaism), the Orange Order, the KKK, and finally anti-Masonic and anti-Jesuit conspiracism in the Spanish Civil War and the Violencia in Colombia. Student research can cover any cult, occult organization or conspiratorial belief since 1450. With any luck we will also touch on a few Asian appropriations of the European occult and conspiracy beliefs touched on earlier, such as the Taiping Rebellion and the Cao Dai religion.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Students will explore scholarly definitions of “cults” (vs religions) and “conspiracy theories” (vs documented closed-door agendas, for example the Wannsee conference) and arrive at a working definition of each which assists them in understanding remaining course readings and provides the intellectual and methodological infrastructure for their own research.
Students will explore and adopt oral history methods in order to compare the internal understanding of members of nonmainstream religious groups about their organization’s history versus external, scholarly, academic, journalistic and mainstream understandings of the same history.
Students will learn to analyze, verbally and in writing, ambiguously fringe, abusive, seditious or otherwise unstable groups with nuance, intellectual rigor and a certain amount of sympathy for members’ self-understanding, including for groups which no longer exist but were important historically. 
Students will explore the contentious historiography around many important nonstandard or new religious/occult/esoteric groups and their contribution to (or lack thereof) major historical events. They will come to understand how conspiracy theories around such groups often have more explanatory power than the groups themselves. 
Students will learn about historical conspiracy theories around unequivocally noncult religious groups (e.g. Protestants, Muslims, Catholics/Jesuits, Jews) and/or ethnic minorities, the accompanying racialization and pathologization of practitioners/members, and associated violence. They will identify patterns of escalation and deescalation and explore questions of demarcation between religious groups and the racialization of religion beginning in the early modern era. 
Students will think critically about which historical assumptions by conspiracists, cult members, witchfinders, and genuine conspirators continue to manifest themselves in the present day, as well as instances of successful “deprogramming” or deescalation of violence in the context of their applicability to the present.

Course Description:
Smart technologies are changing our life and our societies on many levels and continue to give rise to new developments, and new smart and smarter devices. To shape the future, we need creative and interdisciplinary minds with knowledge of science and technology to develop, implement smart technological solutions in our modern society. The most ubiquitous smart device arguably is the smartphone. Physics is the foundation on which those emerging technologies came to exist and have brought about a revolution in the way we communicate and find our way around. The rise of smart appliances and devices for domestic use has changed the way we interact in our daily activities. Understanding how these technologies work, especially with the laws of physics at play, students may develop a profound understanding of these everyday devices and may even appreciate the way they function and perform which alter life for the better. In particular, the smartphone is becoming more sophisticated, versatile, and packed with many advanced technologies on a smaller and smaller scale. In this course we examine how the smartphone glorifies many scientific and technological advancements. These technologies including semiconductor nanotechnology, sensors, fiber optics, satellites, and even atomic clocks form the main subjects to be explored in this course.
---

At the completion of this course, the student will:
Be able to identify a device as a smart device
Be capable of recognizing various essential components of a smart device
Understand the fundamental principles and the functions of the core components of a smart device
Understand the interrelations and/or interconnections of smart devices with the external information networks and the users.
Appreciate everyday smart devices for the way they function and perform which alter life for the better.

Course Description:
This course will introduce students to foundations in literary analysis through texts and materials centered around a common theme of the interconnections between literature, technology, and the category of the human. The title of this course asks: what does it mean to be human? We will expand on that question by also asking: have technological advancements changed the definition of humanity? In what ways does the definition of humanity dependent upon other social factors such as gender, race, dis/ability, class, and nationality? And, how has literature been used as a technology for determining humanity? Through a discussion-based classroom, we will approach these questions by reading and comparing texts from multiple different literary genres, including fiction, poetry, nonfiction, and film. In this course, we will also learn to appreciate the aesthetic and functional quality of texts, focusing on style, intertextuality, and critical value. We will also explore different ways of approaching texts depending on their genre and form, and practice important skills such as close reading, developing arguments, and expressing ideas clearly orally and in writing. Finally, the course will also prompt students to question the value of literature in contemporary society, and how to make connections beyond the material with the world around them.

Course Description:
This class will focus on the genre of epic literature and look to its earliest origins, tracking how epic and heroic narratives have developed from The Epic of Gilgamesh (the earliest known written story) into the early modern era. We will ask: what is epic literature? How do texts construct literary heroes, and why are they important? What role do national heroes and epic figures play in our perception of our own culture, our community, and the outside world? Over the course of the semester, we will discover how foundational texts of epic literature from the often-misunderstood Middle Ages and early modern era ultimately underpin modern epic fantasies like Lord of the Rings, Game of Thrones, or Avatar. Topics may include the power of myth, epic propaganda, the warrior hero, the monstrous other, visions of masculinity throughout time, and the role of women in the hero’s journey. Moreover, this class will look at medieval and early modern epics from a wide variety of cultures, both Western and non-Western, in order to challenge the idea of the universal hero; instead, we will examine how heroic and epic narratives were deeply intertwined with the values and beliefs of the cultures that produced them.

Strengthen reading and analytical skills
Obtain a working knowledge of the epic tradition and compare Western conventions of epic with the epic in other venues (the Middle East, the Far East, etc.)
Understand how literary conventions build over time and deepen our understanding of influence (both horizontal and vertical—intercultural and temporal)

description:

---
Course Description:
Poetry is one of the oldest literary art forms and at first glance also one of the most inaccessible. Yet, in the contemporary moment, people across the world are increasingly (re)turning to poetry as mode of grappling with the inconceivable contradictions of modern life: pandemics, authoritarian regimes, climate change, births and deaths, quotidian celebrations, stubborn joy. “I don’t think poems will save us—us, as in, this country, this world,” writes Marlin M. Jenkins, “But poems continue to save me.” 
What, then, does a poem do? This course introduces students to contemporary poetry by exploring the multifaceted answers to this guiding question. Rather than attempting a comprehensive survey, we will focus our reading to trace poetic actions or what specific poems “do.” In addition to poems, we will also read a selection of prose essays written by poets about poetry. Through our reading, we will situate each poem and its poetic action within the broader sociopolitical and historical context in which it was written. We will also learn to identify and analyze key poetic elements such as form, sound, lyricism, and movement. Readings will mainly consist of poets writing in English post-1975 such as Victoria Chang, Mai Der Vang, Claudia Rankine, Warsan Shire, Philip Metres, and others.

Identify and analyze key poetic elements such as form, sound, and lyricism.
Obtain a working knowledge of key genre differences between poetry and other literary forms (and also important overlaps).

title: Real Analysis
description:
Faculty: Nguyen Trung Hieu - E: trunghieu.nguyen@fulbright.edu.vn
Pre-requisite: MATH101 Calculus
---
Course Description:
What is a real number? Why are there "more" real numbers than rational numbers when both sets of numbers are infinite? If a sequence does not blow up to infinity, does this mean that it must eventually converge? Is there a function that is continuous everywhere but nowhere differentiable? What is the relationship between continuity and integrability? Real Analysis answers these questions and many more. This course revisits familiar topics, such as real numbers, sequences, series, topology in the real line, limits, continuity, and integrals, but studies them in a mathematically rigorous way. It can be the first exposure of students to abstract mathematics, where graphical, numerical, and intuitive arguments are replaced by rigorous mathematical proofs.
---
Course Learning Objectives:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

CLO2. Apply correct proof techniques to prove important theoretical results in real analysis
CLO3. Demonstrate ability to read and write rigorous mathematical proofs

title: Introduction to Music Production
description:
Visiting Faculty: Dana Difilippantonio - E: dana.difilippantonio@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Arts and Humanities (E1)
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course description:
This course aims to provide students with the fundamental level of knowledge required to begin self-producing music. The course will begin with a rudimentary introduction to music theory. Topics will include basics of rhythm, pitch, meter, time signature, scales, and basic chords. Further music theory concepts may be examined throughout the course. At the same time, students will learn how to navigate a modern DAW – in this case, Reaper. Students will be equipped with a set of fully functional VST instruments which require little knowledge to use effectively. Students will learn to apply their music theory knowledge using these virtual instruments. Students will learn about common song structures and rudimentary songwriting and arranging techniques. Students will practice songwriting and music production techniques both solo and in groups. Students are required to provide their own laptop and headphones for the course. All software used within the course is available for free download. Students are encouraged to have a small MIDI-controller, but it is not required.
---
Course Learning outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be expected to demonstrate multiple learning outcomes, including, but not limited to:
• Demonstratse an understanding of fundamental music theory, including rhythms, meter, time signature, major and minor scales, and simple chords.
• Demonstrate familiarity with the basic functions of Reaper, including MIDI editing and use of simple virtual instruments
• Demonstrate an ability to create a simple musical composition, including drums, melodic, and harmonic elements.
• Demonstrate an ability to create work both alone and as part of a group
• Demonstrate an ability to listen to music and identify musical elements such as rhythms, meter, time signature, and form.
• Demonstrate an understanding of project and file management techniques
---
Tentative Syllabus:
Required Materials: Students must provide their own equipment for class. This includes a laptop and mixing headphones. Use of a MIDI controller is optional but encouraged.
Reaper is the required DAW used for class. It can be downloaded for free.
The class will use the collection of free Spitfire Audio “Labs” virtual instruments.
As the field of music production is ever-changing, and can often evolve quite rapidly, there is no specific textbook for the course.
Music theory concepts will be taught, reviewed, and assessed through musictheory.net.
The instructor will provide a curated list of Reaper tutorials for students to review necessary DAW functions and other songwriting concepts.
Tentative Course Schedule:
Unit 1: Fundamentals of Music Theory and Basic Functions of Reaper
Weeks 1-2: Learn how to read and interpret basic musical terms and notation, including note identification, time signature, tempo, and rhythm. Download Reaper and VST software and understand basic DAW functions.
Weeks 3-4: Learn how to construct basic scales and chords and continue to refine musical knowledge.
Learn basics of MIDI editing and how to translate music theory knowledge to the DAW.

Unit 2: Application of Theory in Music Production
Weeks 5-6: Practice applying fundamental rhythmic patterns by creating simple drum parts. Learn how to construct simple melodies and chord progressions.
Weeks 7-8: Continue to refine the previous knowledge and techniques, while learning more functions of Reaper, such as simple automation of volume and other musical parameters.

Unit 3: Basics of Songwriting and Arranging
Weeks 9-10: Learn basic song structure components such as verse, chorus, bridge, etc. Practice imitating these structures while continuing to compose new music within the DAW. Prepare to submit Midterm Project.
Weeks 11-12: Learn basic arranging techniques, such as chord inversions, and apply them to current musical projects to enhance and refine them.

Unit 4: Collaboration
Weeks 13-15: Work collaboratively within a group to produce a finished track with original drum parts, melody, and chord progressions. Classes during these weeks will consist of a mixture of review of class concepts, group work time, and peer review. Projects are due before the final class, which will serve as a group listening and critique of final projects.

This course is designed to be an Engaged Inquiry into psychology, focusing not just on only helping students to get to know what psychology is, but also helping students develop important critical and scientific thinking skills as they engage in collaborative and reflective learning. Through this course, students will be introduced to many of the major topics, concepts, and theories of psychology. Both historical perspectives and current research are included. This course will emphasize ways students can apply psychology to various aspects of everyday life, investigate the impact of culture on psychological processes, and think critically about how psychological research and theory inform contemporary issues. title: Social Inquiry and the Social Sciences
description:
Faculty: Ian Kalman - E: ian.kalman@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Social Sciences (E2)
Pre-requisite: No
This course is required for Social Studies Major and fulfills SURVEY requirements in this major.
---
Course Description:
What is society, and why do we have it?  Humans are unique among living beings in the scale and complexity of our social formations. Through society, we make the worlds we live in - we cultivate identities, families, language, morality, governments, wealth, religions, and so forth. Society makes these things and makes them meaningful; society can turn a piece of paper into money, and money into something people will spend their lives pursuing. Thus, society can and must be studied, and studied with all empirical tools available to researchers. This course, Social Inquiry, provides an introductory survey to the questions and topics at the heart of the social sciences.  Unit one focuses on longstanding questions such as “what is human nature”, “why do we have society in the first place?” and “do individuals make society, or does society make individuals?”, while unit two explores specific topics of interest to social scientists. Some topics for inquiry include: identity, gender and sexuality, economy, politics, inequality, family, law, and language. This course is a required foundational course for the Social Studies major and may be of interest to anyone fulfilling their exploratory requirements as well. 
---
Course Learning Objectives:
Students will be able to demonstrate familiarity with key topics and research approaches in the social sciences through exams and response papers 
Students will be able to understand and employ basic concepts in social science research methods such as “society” in order to interpret fundamental texts 
Students will be able to present and discuss social issues that concern their lives 
---
Tentative Syllabus

Unit One: Foundational Questions
This unit focuses on core questions, and a few core ideas across the social sciences. 
The primary text is David Graeber and David Wengrow’s recent, The Dawn of Everything, but students will also read selections from Max Weber, Marcel Mauss, Emile Durkheim, Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Erving Goffman, Margaret Mead, and Ruth Benedict. 
Each week is organized around a key question such as: “What is society?” “Do people make society?” “Does society make people?” “What is human nature”, “What is human culture”, and “What type of science is social science?”
This unit will culminate in a midterm exam focusing on foundational concepts in the social sciences.  
 Unit Two: The Human Experience
This unit focuses on key topics in social scientific research. 
Each week focuses on a different topic with readings highlighting contemporary and interesting research related to those topis. 
Different iterations of the class can select form a list of topics depending upon the instructor’s preference. These topics include: Food, Sex, Death, Wealth, Nations, Power, Religion, Language, Law, Morality, Race. Readings include Margaret Wilson’s Indulgence, Sidney Mintz’s Sweetness and Power, Renato Rosaldo’s Grief and the Headhunter’s Rage, Marshall Sahlins’ The Original Affluent Societies, Erik Harms’s The Boss, Ernest Gellner’s Nationalism, Benedict Anderson’s Imagined Communities, Alice Goffman’s ‘On the Run’. 
This unit will culminate in short student presentations and discussions, and a cumulative final exam focusing on the application of concepts to contexts selected by the instructor.  
---
Possible Assessments & Grading
Book Report – Students will review and present a book related to a social science topic of their choice. They will then discuss the presentation in a group with their classmates.  
Midterm Exam – Test familiarity with core concepts in social sciences and students’ ability to connect them to contexts provided by the instructor
