title: Case Study Research in Social Sciences
description:
Faculty: Tobias Burgers - E: tobias.burgers@fulbright.edu.vn
Category: Exploratory - Social Sciences (E2)
Pre-requisite: No
---
Course Description:
This course will introduce students to the qualitative research method of case studies. Case studies are among the essential, oldest, and fundamental research methodologies within the spectrum of qualitative research methods in social sciences. In the disciplines of political science, international relations, gender studies, communication, and media studies, among others, case studies are essential methodological tools for conducting research. As Baxter and Jack (2008) note, “Qualitative case study are a valuable method for […] research to develop theory, evaluate programs, and develop interventions” (Baxter & Jack, 2008, p.544). Case studies allow researchers and students to understand complex to generate theories, test theories, and explore new research directions, illustrating their importance as qualitative research methods (Bhattacherje, 2008). 
This course will introduce students to the methodology of case study research and what a case study is. Throughout the course, students will learn about the theoretical framework of case studies, their structure, their importance, and the type of case studies in existence and widely used in social sciences. Furthermore, it discusses and highlights the (ongoing) debate in social sciences on case studies. Subsequently, students will learn how to develop their own case study research design and execute their case study research. 
The sum of this allows students to gain: An in-depth understanding of the importance and utility of case studies as essential research methods in social sciences, as well introduce them to developing research designs, with a particular focus on case study research design and finally gain experience in conducting case study research.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1: Students will learn about qualitative research methods – in particular case study research.
CLO2: Students will understand the importance of case study research, as a research method, and for social sciences.
CLO3: Students will learn how to conduct case study research methods (and apply these to the social sciences).
CLO4: Students gain practical experience conducting case study research
CLO5: Students gain practical experience in conducting research as a team.
CLO6: Develop the ability to evaluate and critique existing case study studies and identify strengths and weaknesses.
---
Tentative Syllabus:
Block 1 Theoretical Foundations
Week 1 Intro
Week 2 Social Science Research and qualitative research methods.
Week 3 What is the case study research?
Week 4 Case study research in social sciences.
Week 5 Case study research. Pros and cons.

Block 2 Type of case studies
Week 6 Descriptive case studies.
Week 7 Explanatory case studies.
Week 8 Exploratory case reports.
Week 9 Semester Break. 
Week 10 Single case studies, comparative case study and multi-site studies. 

Block 3 Practice
Week 11 In class mid term assignment assessment. 
Week 12 From research design to actual research. Start your own case study research. 
Week 13 Peer assessment.
Week 14 End of the term recap. 
--- 
Possible Assessments & Grading:
Block 1 Assessment. Discuss a well or poorly conducted case study (20%). For the first assessment of the course, students are expected to write a 500-word essay focusing on a chosen case study. In this assignment, they will summarize the case study, explain why they chose it, and argue why it was a well-conducted or poorly conducted case study. 
Midterm assessment: Design your case study research design (30%). The midterm aims to have students apply the theoretical foundations they learned and subsequently develop their own case study research design. This assessment will be conducted in groups of 4 to 6 students. The assessment length would be around 2000 words per group submission.
Final term assessment: Execute your case study research (40%). For the final term assignment, students will conduct their case study research, again in a group of 4 to 6 students. Ideally, this is based on their midterm research design, but they can propose an entirely new project if desired. This assessment aims to have students learn how to conduct their own case study research. Students will use the final block “practice” to execute their research design. In-class hours will be used to discuss research designs and execution, guide students, and for peer assessment. The expected length of their case study is about 3000 words per group submission. 
Attendance (10%). Students are expected to participate in all classes, with a maximum of 3 classes absent. Furthermore, in class discussion is expected.

description:

Course Description:
What is ethics? And why should we care about it? Simply defined, ethics can be understood as a system of moral principles. As stated by Aristotle in his Nicomachean Ethics, “We are not concerned to know what goodness is but how to become good [people]…, since otherwise our inquiry would be useless.” This course introduces students to key texts and concepts in the study of ethics and moral philosophy. Students will connect theoretical approaches to the study of morality to one another, and to their own lives.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:

2. Demonstrate familiarity with classic texts and arguments related to ethics and moral philosophy through discussion and short- and long-form writing
3. Demonstrate familiarity with the broader intellectual history and context of ethical and moral reasoning through discussion and short- and long-form writing
4. Connect classical philosophical theories to contemporary local and global contexts through discussion and short- and long-form writing.
---
Tentative Schedule:
Part One - Classical Approaches: Epistemology We begin our class with an examination of philosophy in general.
We ask ourselves - what is philosophy for? What is wisdom? What does it do? How can we go from ignorance to knowledge?
Week One - Introductions, Apologies

Part Two - Classical Approaches: Virtue Ethics in the East and West
We move to the first of the three most well known schools of moral philosophy - Virtue Ethics, which argues that virtuous action is necessary for the good life. We juxtapose the thoughts of two highly influential philosophers who lived around the same time in very different places, Aristotle and Confucius.
Week Three - Happiness and Virtue
Week Four - Friendship and Love
Week Five - Confucian Virtue Ethics

Part Three - Nature and Culture - Social Contract and Natural Law Theory
In this section, we will discuss the significance of such concepts as “natural law”, “rights”, “legitimacy”, and “liberty” in the formulation of moral philosophy from the enlightenment onwards. After introducing the concept of natural law developed by Aquinas to reconcile contradictions between christian and aristotelian moral worldviews, we look at how the idea of “nature” has shaped philosophical thinking from Hobbes onwards.

Week Eight - Social Contract

title: Language, Culture and Thought
description:
Faculty: Ian Scott Kalman – E: ian.kalman@fulbright.edu.vn
Pre-requisite: For 3rd year +
Reading/Writing: Intensive
* Cross-listed with PSY
---
Course Description:
What is language - and could we even ask this question without it? Among all animals, humans are unique – not in our ability to communicate, but in the depth and extent of that ability. Language is not just about communication, words such as “I now pronounce you man and wife” can fundamentally change someone’s legal and personal identity.  
Language is intimately tied to experience – the way we talk about an event has a bearing on how we understand that event – were those words “just a joke”, or an insult? As much as language is something that humans produce, language is also part of what makes us human.  
This course explores the complex intersection of language, culture, and thought through an introduction to sociolinguistics and linguistic anthropology. Our course is divided into two principle units – firstly, we examine the history and core concepts in the study of language, beginning with philosophical questions on the origins of human language, the creation of linguistics as a distinct field of research, and the terms by which scholars have considered the relationships between language and culture.  Core concepts include linguistic relativity, semiotics, illocutionary acts, and framing. In the second unit, we investigate language in everyday life. Core themes include power, gender, ideology, and identity.  
Please note, this is not a linguistics course. We will not be learning new languages or emphasizing the technical components of syntax and use. While we will draw examples from many languages throughout the world, strong English reading and writing skills are highly recommended, as many core texts will be in English and draw upon English.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
Students Will Be Able To:
• Understand the history and core concepts in sociolinguistics and linguistic anthropology as it commonly appears in academic texts.
• Identify the role of language in their own culture and thought with increasing amounts of subtlety and depth.  
• Employ key concepts from sociolinguistics in oral discussions and both a written paper and exam.  
• Develop and execute a research project relating to language, culture, and thought in their own lives.

Course Description:
Vietnam today confronts the urgent question: how to balance the imperatives of developing sustainably and of safeguarding its cultural heritage and identity? The SRV Constitution’s goal of building “a progressive culture deeply imbued with national identity” has guided Vietnamese policy since 1992 and figures into national strategies for sustainable development for the coming decades. Similar challenges have faced many countries around the world as they undergo rapid industrialization and post-industrialization. Responding to those challenges, an array of international treaties has been developed to support national efforts and international cooperation.
This 300-level course provides an overview of the development and evolution of concepts of “cultural heritage” over the past century and around the world, examines the existing international legal framework, and analyzes Vietnamese responses (legal and regulatory as well as practical). The course approaches heritage from the perspectives of anthropology and critical heritage studies, combining intensive analyses of heritage policy with case studies of how such policies are applied on the ground. Special attention will be given to examining recent controversies in Vietnam over different aspects of cultural heritage. The focus will be on built cultural heritage (monuments and relics) and intangible cultural heritage.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1: Situate Vietnam’s approach to cultural heritage within global trends and frameworks, highlighting the Vietnamization of those international concepts and approaches
CLO2: Develop critical reading skills as applied to international treaties, Vietnamese domestic laws, and Vietnamese implementing regulations, emphasizing responsibilities of citizens and the state
CLO3: Research and analyze current cases and controversies in Vietnam’s application of international heritage treaties and domestic heritage laws, highlighting critical contributions of leading Vietnamese scholars
CLO4: Understand how issues of heritage and identity pose fundamental challenges to Vietnamese citizens, especially young ones, as they seek to ensure a sustainable future

Course Description:
Technology is omnipresent in our lives and has shaped, currently, and will shape much of modern society's functioning. Its impact, both positive and negative, has economic, ethical, political, and sociological consequences and alters every aspect of our society. This impact process has been, however one in which accountability has been difficult. Such brings up the question: Can we control technological development? Should we even? If so, by what means, by whom, how, under which conditions, and with which tools?  
The question of how to address these issues is at the heart of studies by scholars of governance. Governance refers to "all processes of governing, whether undertaken by a government, market, or network, whether over a family, tribe, formal or informal organization, or territory, and whether through laws, norms, power or language. Governance differs from government in that it focuses less on the state and its institutions and more on social practices and activities." (Bevir, 2012). 
This course provides an overview of how society seeks to control, steer, and manage technology and technological change. It will introduce students to critical actors and concepts of governance and technological governance and the role of various actors in this process. Students will learn to answer questions, such as identifying technological change, what role society has in this process, what political, legal, ethical, and social frameworks exist for such governance, and who decides the governance conditions. 
Using case studies on the internet, AI technology, and climate change, students will apply the theoretical learnings of this course practically, enabling them to think, engage, and write critically about technology and technological governance.

CLO 2 Students will scientifically research on governance, technological change and tech governance.

CLO 4 Students will learn, understand and analyze how society react, and (seeks to) control technology and its impact.

description:

Course Description:
Vietnam today is witnessing a proliferation of new and renovated museums and the growth of a dynamic “museum culture”, transforming once-stodgy institutions into important venues for education and civic discourse. Students will explore how various museums in HCMC conceive and represent Vietnamese culture, society, and history. 
Students will look at the public face of museums as presented to visitors and will have opportunities for behind-the-scenes interaction with senior museum personnel. Museum visits by the class are integrated into the course schedule. Background readings will introduce the history of museums in Vietnam and will provide an overview of the primary technologies that museums employ (objects and artifacts, documents and images, texts and labels). Comparative readings will situate the Vietnamese museum experience within its Asian context, showing how museums in neighboring countries have approached similar issues.
The course has two main threads: one is historical (how do Vietnamese museums define and portray heroes and enemies?) and the other anthropological (how do Vietnamese museums define the nation and present its ethnicities?). The first will consider historical displays within specialized museums devoted to revolution and peace and “general museums” in HCMC. The second will examine how Vietnam’s ethnicities are imagined and presented in the ethnographic displays in those same HCMC general museums.
The course will appeal to students interested in issues of representation and Vietnamese identity, whether from a historical perspective or an ethnographic one. It will help prepare them to be active citizens in Vietnamese society and, it is hoped, will infect some of them with the museological bug so that they may consider careers in one or another aspect of museum practice.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
CLO1: Understand the history and development of Vietnamese museums, in a national and regional context, and their role in contemporary society.
CLO2: Learn to experience museums with a sophisticated appreciation of the technologies they employ (objects and artifacts, documents and images, texts and labels).

title: Going Hand in Hand: Politics and Economic Development in Contemporary Vietnam
description:
Faculty: Nguyen Thanh Trung - E: trung.nguyen@fulbright.edu.vn

---
Course Description:
To help Vietnam become an active participant in today’s world requires a basic understanding of the country and the broader Asia-Pacific region. The past three decades have seen Vietnam increasingly rising as a political as well as economic power in the Southeast Asian region. Given its growing economic size and political influence, Vietnam’s regional footprint is progressively noticeable. This course helps students understand how politics, history, culture, and customs could have an impact on the rapidly changing economy and society in contemporary Vietnam. It will focus on the discussion how political, economic and social forces shape a “socialism-oriented market economy” as the Vietnamese government claims. Put simply, the primary focus is on the interrelationships among individuals, governments, and public policy. The course is organized into two broad primary portions: 1) The history of Vietnam and the Vietnam’s economic renovation (Doi Moi) since 1986; and 2) Contemporary issues the country is facing. This first part will only capture the key periods and turning points in historical Vietnam, which is necessary for understanding how historical institutions continue to shape the nation’s politics and economy today. The remainder of the course will be on the Vietnamese economic reform since 1986 and contemporary issues, with an emphasis on the relationship between politics and economic development, plus cross-country comparisons as well as key challenges facing the Vietnamese Communist Party leadership, such as regime stability, pollution, and political reform.
---
Course Learning Outcomes:
At the end of this course, the ultimate objectives of this course are that students should have a familiarity with and knowledge of 
Vietnam from the interplay of the so-called socialist ideology and “socialism-oriented market economy,” 
The hierarchical structure and decision-making process of the Vietnamese government, 
The distinctive dynamic of politics, economy, and legal system in Vietnam, and how it differs from other western models. 
The course improves students’ ability to think about Vietnam’s complex development more comprehensively and critically; and 
It also enables students to integrate what they have learned into other Vietnam-related courses in their chosen academic (inter-)discipline(s).

Course Description: This course introduces students to several crucial aspects of Vietnam Studies as an inter-/trans-disciplinary field and a part of regional studies. Students will first learn what “transdisciplinarity” and “area/regional studies” are, what regional studies we are talking about when talking about Vietnam, and why they are playing important roles in our understanding of the country and its people. Key concepts in social sciences and the humanities (such as “power,” “society,” “culture,” “nation-state,” “national identity,” “national pride,” “colonial mentality,” “inferiority complex,” or “globalization”) will be discussed to create a basic theoretical foundation for further understanding of multiple “Vietnams” in the making. Students will have the opportunity to examine a few case studies, approve or question their research outcomes with a critical mind. Students will also have a chance to learn about local studies, recognizing the importance of the studies of urban centers and rural areas, such as Ho Chi Minh City (formerly, Saigon), Hue, Hanoi, or the Mekong Delta that will enrich their comprehension of those places and of Vietnam, in general. Students will be exposed to “Vietnamese Studies” currently practiced inside and outside Vietnam to realize which approaches have been employed in this interdisciplinary field, and how the field significantly varies in different geo-political, socio-cultural environments, depending on who is doing it and in which contexts it is carried out. A wide array of (re)sources for study and research will be introduced. Finally, students will have a chance to redefine “Vietnam Studies” at Fulbright University Vietnam and figure out which directions it is heading towards. This course is open to VS majors and non-majors.

title: Cultural and Intellectual Foundation of Vietnamese Literary Chinese II
description:
Visiting Faculty: Phan Thu Van - E: van.phan@fulbright.edu.vn
Reading/Writing: Intensive
Pre-requisite: VS106 Cultural and Intellectual Foundation of Vietnamese Literary Chinese 1.
* Cross-listed with Literature (LIT)
---
Course Description:
Vietnamese Literary Chinese is an important part of the formation of Vietnamese culture and ideology. Vietnamese people were employing and localizing Chinese scripts and literary Chinese throughout more than 10 centuries (from the 10th to the beginning of the 20th centuries). As the official written language of the country for the composition of a wide variety of works, such as histories, literature, diplomatic documents, or medical treatises, this linguistic means helped the Vietnamese to record their thoughts and cultural values through times. The Vietnamese localization of the written Chinese resulted not only in new syntactic and lexical variations, but also in the emergence of a new phonetic system called Sino-Vietnamese pronunciation (âm Hán-Việt) for Chinese scripts.
Nowadays, words and morphemes rooted from literary Chinese may account for up to 60% of the vocabulary written in formal and scientific texts. Hence, understanding Vietnamese literary Chinese, and being literate in Chinese scripts obviously a key to comprehend Vietnam’s past and present, to better understand the nation’s cultural and intellectual heritage in East Asian contexts. Like the crucial role of Latin in American-European academes, knowledge of Vietnamese literary Chinese and Sino-Vietnamese words is definitely required for any student in Vietnam Studies in general, and pre-modern Vietnam research in particular. Based on Chinese scripts, the Vietnamese invented a new writing system, popular known as the demotic Nom script, to express their thoughts and emotions in their mother tongue. However, one cannot read Nom without knowing Chinese characters. Therefore, for Vietnamese people, learning Vietnamese literary Chinese and Sino-Vietnamese characters means more than learning a language. It helps to bridge a huge gap between young Vietnamese learners and the historico-cultural textual treasure they are inheriting from the past.
---
Course Learning Outcomes: Having finished this course, students will:
1. Have basic knowledge of Vietnamese Literary Chinese (writing, reading, grammar)
2. Attain a vocabulary of 800 words of Vietnamese Literary Chinese.
3. Gain the ability to read poems or tales in Vietnamese Literary Chinese.
4. Establish basic understanding of Vietnamese classical literature and Vietnamese literary Chinese heritage (including Vietnamese Literary Chinese in temples, or at historical sites)
5. Have greater appreciation of Vietnamese language and culture.

Course Description:
Originally part of Buddhist teaching, “Mindfulness” has now become a popular practice all over the world, widely spread in both academic and social lives. In this course, it will be examined from a secular perspective. Taught in a pre-seminar teaching format that combines lectures with in-class discussions, the course employs an interdisciplinary approach that allows students to understand this concept/practice through a variety of lenses, such as history, culture, and applied psychology. Following this direction, Secular mindfulness will be examined historically to see the formation, reconstruction, and transmission of it from wartime Vietnam to the world and back to postwar developing Vietnam. Moreover, during this course, students will have the chance to practice mindfulness and reflect on it in familial, communal, national, and international contexts. In addition to equipping students with academic understanding of and scholarly approaches to secular mindfulness, mindfulness practices introduced in the course may also help students build and develop a healthy mental lifestyle.

Course Description:
Home to four of the five most populous states and four of the five largest economies, the Asia/Pacific is arguably the most dynamic region in the twenty-first century. At the same time, Cold War remnants (a divided Korea and China) and major geopolitical shifts (the rise of China and India, decline of US and Japan) contribute significantly to the volatility of our world. This course will examine the political, economic, and geopolitical dynamism of the region through a survey of relations among the great powers in East Asia from the sixteenth century to the present. Special emphasis will be given to regional and global developments from the perspective of the four principal East Asian states—China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam. We will explore the many informal, as well as formal, means of intercourse that have made East Asia what it is today.
---
Learning Outcomes:
(CLO1) History: Students will develop a broad grasp of East Asian diplomacy and a deep understanding of specific events and historical figures.  
(CLO2) Reading: Students will learn to distinguish between primary and secondary sources and between scholarly and non-scholarly texts. They will also learn to critically evaluate texts. 
(CLO3) Expression: Students will hone their skills in both written and oral expression. 
(CLO4) Interpretation: Students will recognize competing narratives and make judgments about such narratives through context and appreciation of historical contingency.
